abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Project Completion Report
            (PCR) for the Agricultural Sector Adjustment Operation
            (ASAO) in Kenya. At the beginning of the 1980s, the Kenyan
            economy had large financial imbalances, resulting from a
            deterioration of external terms of trade following the
            second oil shock, and an erosion of fiscal discipline.
            Domestic demand exceeded domestic supply, government
            expenditures exceeded revenues, and imports exceeded
            exports. During the early 1980s, economic growth was
            erratic, and the slow growth of agriculture was a particular
            cause of concern because of the critical links between
            agriculture and the rest of the economy. The project
            objectives can be stated as follows: Taking overall growth
            strategy as its starting point, the ASAO was growth-oriented
            and included key actions to assist government implement
            three inter-related strategies: intensifying production
            through increased supplies of key inputs; enhanced producer
            incentives and market de-regulation; and improved allocation
            and efficiency of sectoral public investments and
            expenditures. The quality and speed of ASAO implementation
            suffered after an initial satisfactory phase. Towards the
            latter part of the implementation period in 1987, the
            Government appeared to be more committed to fulfilling the
            vaguely defined conditions for tranche release, than to full
            implementation of a reform program. While the direction of
            the policy reforms has remained on track in most areas, the
            timeliness and extent of full implementation have fallen
            short of expectations. The six main lessons related to the
            project are in the following areas: (a) Government
            commitment and sustainability ;( b) program design; (c)
            disbursements and allocation of funds; (d) implementation
            and coordination arrangements; (e) complementarity with
            other investments and programs; and (f) the usefulness of
            ASAO as an instrument for mobilizing multi-donor support
            within a policy framework.

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Agricultural Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project will support the first phase of
            implementation of the Government's program of
            adjustments in the agricultural sector.  The principal
            objectives of the program are to stimulate sectoral growth
            through promoting intensification of production and better
            use of Kenya's limited land; improve producer
            incentives; and expand the flow of investment resources to
            the sector.  Above all, the program is geared to lifting the
            obstacles to increased production by the 1.9 million
            smallholder farm families who are the backbone of
            Kenya's agricultural sector.  To achieve these
            objectives, actions have been taken and others will be
            implemented in the following two years. They will include
            (i) improving the availability of key agricultural inputs
            and services; (ii) increasing production and investment
            incentives, (iii) implementing programs to address critical
            parastatal problems; (iv) launching a major restructuring of
            the public investment and expenditure program; and (v)
            increasing flows of credit and expanding access to credit,
            particularly for smallholders.  The foreign exchange
            provided by the Credits will be used to finance an agreed
            program of imports of inputs needed for the sector.
